title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: ‘South Park' Creators' Face Challenger; Santa Fe Hotel Wins Bankruptcy Exit; Brazos Keeps $1.9 Billion Electricity Lawsuit Alive
text:
‘South Park' creators face rival bid for Casa Bonita. A devoted fan of bankrupt restaurant and entertainment center Casa Bonita, famed for its appearance on "South Park," said in court papers Monday that he can do better than the proposed sale to the show's creators, Trey Parker and Matt Stone. Their offer would pay $3.1 million for Casa Bonita, known for its 30-foot high waterfall, which cliff divers jump off to entertain guests.

Santa Fe hotel Bishop's Lodge cleared for lender takeover. The Bishop's Lodge hotel in Santa Fe, N.M., won approval to hand itself over to Juniper Investment Advisors LLC, defeating a minority investor who argued the luxury property didn't do enough to market itself. The resort filed for chapter 11 protection in August, blaming Covid-19 lockdowns, construction delays and cost overruns.

Bankruptcy judge agrees to hear Brazos' challenge to Texas storm bills. The judge overseeing Brazos Electric Power Cooperative Inc.'s bankruptcy case retained jurisdiction over the co-op's challenge to the nearly $1.9 billion it was billed during the winter storm that swept Texas in February. The ruling is a setback for Texas power regulators, who argued that Texas state courts should decide how much Brazos owes, rather than the bankruptcy court.

Bankruptcy

Talc claimants fight J&J bid to pause lawsuits. Personal injury claimants alleging the talc in Johnson & Johnson baby powder caused cancer are opposing an attempt to use a subsidiary's chapter 11 filing to pause litigation against the company.

A committee representing roughly 35,000 talc injury claimants said in a court filing Tuesday that litigation against J&J itself should continue after a newly formed subsidiary filed chapter 11 in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Charlotte.

The committee said the J&J subsidiary, LTL Management LLC, is attempting to "run roughshod over the talc victims" in seeking a broad chapter 11 stay that would protect corporate affiliates, including the publicly-traded parent company. — Jonathan Randles

USA Gymnastics finalizing bankruptcy plan voting materials. A lawyer for the governing body of American gymnastics said Tuesday they are circulating materials for sex abuse victims and other creditors who will vote on the organization's bankruptcy plan.

The governing body for American gymnastics has been revising documents underpinning its disclosure statement, a key bankruptcy docket that outlines the terms of a chapter 11 plan for creditors. Judge Robyn Moberly of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Indianapolis said during a hearing she will consider approving the disclosure statement at a hearing scheduled for next week. USA Gymnastics filed for chapter 11 in 2018 to resolve claims arising from decadeslong sexual abuse by the national team's former doctor, Larry Nassar. — Jonathan Randles

Business forum organizer Richmond Events files chapter 11. Richmond Events filed for chapter 11, one of numerous organizations in the live-events industry to do so during the Covid-19 pandemic. Richmond, which organizes business forums and networking events, has hosted hundreds of events in the U.S., U.K., Switzerland and Italy since launching in 1999, according to its website.

The New York-based company listed among its debt more than $488,000 in coronavirus relief loans obtained through the federal government's Paycheck Protection Program to cover employee wages and other expenses. Richmond made its filing in the US Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. — Jonathan Randles

Distress

Lawmakers turn spotlight on private equity. U.S. lawmakers will subject the private-equity industry to fresh scrutiny over its practices, and some members of Congress plan to revive a bill to increase federal regulation of buyout firms. Hearings on Wednesday and Thursday should cast a light on lawmakers' attitudes toward the private-equity industry under a Democratic-controlled Congress. Witnesses scheduled to speak include workers, representatives of organized labor, advocacy groups and investors in private equity.

Assets controlled by the buyout industry, according to McKinsey

International

Credit Suisse to admits to defrauding investors over Mozambique loans. Credit Suisse Group AG agreed to pay $475 million and forgive $200 million Mozambique owes to investors in coordinated settlements with U.S. and European authorities over loans the bank made in the country.

The settlements draw a line under an eight-year-old scandal that has seen three former Credit Suisse bankers plead guilty for their roles in siphoning hundreds of millions of dollars that the bank helped raise for companies owned by the African country's government. The U.K. regulator said the loans, arranged in 2013 and 2014, were "tainted by corruption."

In Other News

A bankrupt couple's failure to list a mortgage-related lawsuit in their schedule of assets doomed their ability to get the settlement proceeds from the case, a federal appeals court ruled. (Bloomberg)

Bonuses for executives of bankrupt companies have been commonplace for many years now, occurring either during a bankruptcy or shortly before a company files its Chapter 11 petition. Now, politicians on both sides of the aisle have decided it's time to rein that practice in. (Reuters)
